titleInfo.title: RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE

extension.searchTitle: RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 50

congVote.result: So the motion to table was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Representative Polis rose to a question of the privileges of the House and submitted a resolution. The Chair ruled that the resolution did not present a question of the privileges of the House. Subsequently, Representative Polis appealed the ruling of the chair and Representative Cheney moved to table the appeal. Agreed to the motion to table the appeal of the ruling of the Chair by a yea-and-nay vote of 230 yeas to 189 nays with 1 answering ``present'', Roll No. 182.

titleInfo.title: COMPETITIVE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM ACT OF 2017

extension.searchTitle: COMPETITIVE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM ACT OF 2017; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 50

congVote.result: So the motion to recommit was rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Competitive Health Insurance Reform Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 372, to restore the application of the Federal antitrust laws to the business of health insurance to protect competition and consumers, by a recorded vote of 416 ayes to 7 noes, Roll No. 184. Consideration began yesterday, March 21st.<P/>Rejected the Rosen motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by a yea-and-nay vote of 189 yeas to 233 nays, Roll No. 183.

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Competitive Health Insurance Reform Act of 2017
Competitive Health Insurance Reform Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 372, to restore the application of the Federal antitrust laws to the business of health insurance to protect competition and consumers, by a recorded vote of 416 ayes to 7 noes, Roll No. 184. Consideration began yesterday, March 21st.

The House passed H.R. 372, to restore the application of the Federal antitrust laws to the business of health insurance to protect competition and consumers, by a recorded vote of 416 ayes to 7 noes, Roll No. 184. Consideration began yesterday, March 21st.<P/>Rejected the Rosen motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by a yea-and-nay vote of 189 yeas to 233 nays, Roll No. 183.

titleInfo.title: SMALL BUSINESS HEALTH FAIRNESS ACT OF 2017

name.namePart: Committee on Education and the Workforce
Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

extension.searchTitle: SMALL BUSINESS HEALTH FAIRNESS ACT OF 2017; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 50

congVote.result: So the motion to recommit was rejected.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Small Business Health Fairness Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 1101, to amend title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to improve access and choice for entrepreneurs with small businesses with respect to medical care for their employees, by a recorded vote of 236 ayes to 175 noes, Roll No. 186.<P/>Rejected the Shea Porter motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Education and the Workforce with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by a yea-and-nay vote of 179 yeas to 233 nays, Roll No. 185.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-9 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Education and the Workforce now printed in the bill.

congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Small Business Health Fairness Act of 2017
Small Business Health Fairness Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 1101, to amend title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to improve access and choice for entrepreneurs with small businesses with respect to medical care for their employees, by a recorded vote of 236 ayes to 175 noes, Roll No. 186.

The House passed H.R. 1101, to amend title I of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to improve access and choice for entrepreneurs with small businesses with respect to medical care for their employees, by a recorded vote of 236 ayes to 175 noes, Roll No. 186.<P/>Rejected the Shea Porter motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Education and the Workforce with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with an amendment, by a yea-and-nay vote of 179 yeas to 233 nays, Roll No. 185.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-9 shall be considered as adopted, in lieu of the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on Education and the Workforce now printed in the bill.

titleInfo.title: United States House Amendment Number 1 (115th Congress)
United States House Amendment Number 1 (115th Congress)
SECURING OUR AGRICULTURE AND FOOD ACT

extension.searchTitle: SECURING OUR AGRICULTURE AND FOOD ACT; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 50

congVote.result: So (two-thirds being in the affirmative) the rules were suspended and the bill was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Securing our Agriculture and Food Act
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to suspend the rules and pass the following measure:<P/>H.R. 1238, to amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to make the Assistant Secretary of Homeland Security for Health Affairs responsible for coordinating the efforts of the Department of Homeland Security related to food, agriculture, and veterinary defense against terrorism, by a \2/3\ yea-and-nay vote of 406 yeas to 6 nays, Roll No. 187.

congVote.result: The joint resolution (H.J. Res. 83) was passed.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory2: Clarification of Employer's Continuing Obligation to Make and Maintain an Accurate Record of Each Recordable Injury and Illness Rule
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: <P/>By 50 yeas to 48 nays (Vote No. 93), Senate passed H.J. Res. 83, disapproving the rule submitted by the Department of Labor relating to ``Clarification of Employer's Continuing Obligation to Make and Maintain an Accurate Record of Each Recordable Injury and Illness'', after agreeing to the motion to proceed.
